elements.content: From the perspective of preset configuration of ligands, the introduction of triazole would be not only conducive to furnish sites rich in nitrogen, but also favorable to enhance the stability of MOF materials. Through employing two similar bifunctional triazolate–carboxylate organic ligands, two novel self-interpenetrating copper­(II)-based metal–organic frameworks have been successfully constructed under solvothermal conditions, which exhibit very similar voids but different hole shapes. In addition, powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry, gas sorption studies, and theoretical calculations reveal their different framework stabilities and pore environment.
elements.clean_text: From the perspective of preset configuration of ligands, the introduction of triazole would be not only conducive to furnish sites rich in nitrogen, but also favorable to enhance the stability of MOF materials. Through employing two similar bifunctional triazolate-carboxylate organic ligands, two novel self-interpenetrating copper(II)-based metal-organic frameworks have been successfully constructed under solvothermal conditions, which exhibit very similar voids but different hole shapes. In addition, powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry, gas sorption studies, and theoretical calculations reveal their different framework stabilities and pore environment.

elements.content: Based on the similar bifunctional triazolate−carboxylate linkers, two novel self-interpenetrating MOFs with high stabilities and porosities have been successfully assembled. In addition, we have explored the different framework stabilities and pore environment of Cu-MOFs 1-2 by powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry, gas sorption, and theoretical calculations, which indicates the important role of the careful predesigned ligands.
elements.clean_text: Based on the similar bifunctional triazolate-carboxylate linkers, two novel self-interpenetrating MOFs with high stabilities and porosities have been successfully assembled. In addition, we have explored the different framework stabilities and pore environment of Cu-MOFs 1-2 by powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry, gas sorption, and theoretical calculations, which indicates the important role of the careful predesigned ligands.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) could be constructed by the versatile connection modes between metal nodes and organic linkers, which have been recognized as one booming type of porous material. Thanks to the excellent porous structures, MOFs have shown wide potential applications in many fields such as small molecule separation, gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, chemical sensors, photoluminescence, and so on. The definite preparation of MOFs has been restricted by many factors, including the coordination habits of secondary building units (SBUs), conformations of used ligands, and reaction conditions. Currently, the core issue in the field is still how to effectively build the anticipated topological structures with stable porous structures. As an important subgroup of MOFs, the investigation into the field of interpenetrating MOFs has been flourishing due to their fascinating structural–activity relationships. Although the formation of interpenetration would reduce the solvent accessible voids of a single framework, to some extent the large porous area could be reserved in the final packing structure. Beyond that, however, the stability of materials should be improved because of the existence of multiple weak interactions between the independent frameworks. Usually, the interpenetration could be observed in multiple-fold interpenetrating MOFs, whose components consist of multiple networks with the characteristics of the same topology and isolation. The interpenetrating degree mainly depends on the utilization of long bridging ligands and the capacity of a single network. The development of multiple-fold interpenetrating MOFs has gained great attention, and achieved considerable progress. However, systematic research is still needed with consideration of the practical applications of interpenetrating MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) could be constructed by the versatile connection modes between metal nodes and organic linkers, which have been recognized as one booming type of porous material. Thanks to the excellent porous structures, MOFs have shown wide potential applications in many fields such as small molecule separation, gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, chemical sensors, photoluminescence, and so on. The definite preparation of MOFs has been restricted by many factors, including the coordination habits of secondary building units (SBUs), conformations of used ligands, and reaction conditions. Currently, the core issue in the field is still how to effectively build the anticipated topological structures with stable porous structures. As an important subgroup of MOFs, the investigation into the field of interpenetrating MOFs has been flourishing due to their fascinating structural-activity relationships. Although the formation of interpenetration would reduce the solvent accessible voids of a single framework, to some extent the large porous area could be reserved in the final packing structure. Beyond that, however, the stability of materials should be improved because of the existence of multiple weak interactions between the independent frameworks. Usually, the interpenetration could be observed in multiple-fold interpenetrating MOFs, whose components consist of multiple networks with the characteristics of the same topology and isolation. The interpenetrating degree mainly depends on the utilization of long bridging ligands and the capacity of a single network. The development of multiple-fold interpenetrating MOFs has gained great attention, and achieved considerable progress. However, systematic research is still needed with consideration of the practical applications of interpenetrating MOFs.

elements.content: As a very special type of interpenetrating MOF, self-interpenetrating MOFs refer to one independent framework, which consists of the catenation of the same topological rings. The smallest topological components are mainly joined through the coordination bond, which would be more beneficial for the stable porous structure compared to multifold interpenetration. However, knowledge about this self-interpenetrating MOF is very limited compared to the progress on other interpenetrating MOFs. Therefore, how to effectively control assembly of self-interpenetrating MOFs still remains a great challenge in coordination chemistry, which deserves to attract more attention aimed at prompting the development of related research fields. Based on the previous research, it can be envisioned that the conformation of organic linkers affects structural interpenetration in MOFs. One strategy of introducing additional nitrogen coordination sites onto the specific position of linkers could be an alternative approach to construct the self-interpenetrating MOFs with stable porous structure. The N-containing units would occupy the axial positions of Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel SBU, which contributes the formation of self-interpenetrating MOFs. Inspired by the presented synthesis strategy, the triazole group was tentatively settled on the component of dicarboxyl bridges to produce two similar bifunctional ligands. The presence of triazole groups on the organic ligand is not only able to control structural interpenetration in MOFs, but also able to enhance the stability of MOF materials in water. In addition, the interpenetration control in MOFs could be manipulated via a simple change in the ligand by replacing a C–C bond with a C–N bond. Some degree of torsion between the central and outer phenyl rings in the carbon- or nitrogen-centered versions of the ligand may contribute to exclusive framework interpenetration. Therefore, two structurally similar ligands have been employed to react with Cu­(II) to produce MOFs with different degrees of interpenetration under similar conditions. All of the additional advantages are very useful to construct the porous MOFs materials with the desired adsorption properties. Consistent with our assumption, two distinct self-interpenetrating MOFs, [Cu2(L1)2] (1, H2L1 = 4-{bis­(4-benzoic)­amino}-4H-1,2,4-triazole) and [Cu2(L2)2] (2, H2L2 = 4,4′-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethylene)­bis-benzoic acid), have been constructed, which were further structurally characterized and investigated.

The smallest topological components are mainly joined through the coordination bond, which would be more beneficial for the stable porous structure compared to multifold interpenetration. However, knowledge about this self-interpenetrating MOF is very limited compared to the progress on other interpenetrating MOFs. Therefore, how to effectively control assembly of self-interpenetrating MOFs still remains a great challenge in coordination chemistry, which deserves to attract more attention aimed at prompting the development of related research fields. Based on the previous research, it can be envisioned that the conformation of organic linkers affects structural interpenetration in MOFs. One strategy of introducing additional nitrogen coordination sites onto the specific position of linkers could be an alternative approach to construct the self-interpenetrating MOFs with stable porous structure. The N-containing units would occupy the axial positions of Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel SBU, which contributes the formation of self-interpenetrating MOFs. Inspired by the presented synthesis strategy, the triazole group was tentatively settled on the component of dicarboxyl bridges to produce two similar bifunctional ligands. Therefore, two structurally similar ligands have been employed to react with Cu(II) to produce MOFs with different degrees of interpenetration under similar conditions. elements.content: All of the titled crystalline samples have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions with different solvent systems.The existence of carboxyl groups and triazole groups could be validated by the absorption peaks in IR spectra around 1624, 1568, and 1395 cm–1, and 1653, 1563, and 1404 cm–1, which are assigned to the characteristic groups of the aromatic CC and CN vibrations (). The crystal data of two as-synthesized crystal samples were collected at room temperature, and corresponding parameters including crystal data and bond lengths have been gathered in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

All of the titled crystalline samples have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions with different solvent systems.The existence of carboxyl groups and triazole groups could be validated by the absorption peaks in IR spectra around 1624, 1568, and 1395 cm-1, and 1653, 1563, and 1404 cm-1, which are assigned to the characteristic groups of the aromatic CC and CN vibrations (). The crystal data of two as-synthesized crystal samples were collected at room temperature, and corresponding parameters including crystal data and bond lengths have been gathered in .

elements.content: 1 is in trigonal space group R3̅, whose asymmetric unit contains one copper atom and one L1 ligand (a). The copper atom adopts five-coordinated square-pyramidal geometry, and coordinates with four oxygen atoms from the different carboxyls of L1 and one nitrogen atom of triazole. The adjacent copper atoms are bound together via four syn-syn carboxyl groups to form the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel SBU with Cu···Cu distance of 2.639(2) Å. Cu–O distances fall in the range from 1.937(3) to 1.983(5) Å, while Cu–N bond length is 2.139(6) Å, in accordance with the typical values observed in other copper-paddlewheel SBUs. Each L1 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form NbO topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {64·82} calculated with TOPOS. Two identical NbO networks are further bound together via the Cu–N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in a different single network, and then the self-interpenetrating 3,6T18 MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4·62}2{42·610·83} calculated with TOPOS. Despite the presentation of self-interpenetrating structure, two types of 1D channels are still retained in the final packing structure (a,b). The diameters of hexagonal and trigonal channels are about 1.1 and 0.4 nm measured from the crystal structure. Only one nitrogen atom in triazole is used to coordinate with copper atoms, and the other one is reserved and decorated on the surface of channels. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 70.2% (12601.0 Å3/17955.0 Å3) by PLATON.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 1 and 2 

 1 is in trigonal space group R3̅, whose asymmetric unit contains one copper atom and one L1 ligand (a). The copper atom adopts five-coordinated square-pyramidal geometry, and coordinates with four oxygen atoms from the different carboxyls of L1 and one nitrogen atom of triazole. The adjacent copper atoms are bound together via four syn-syn carboxyl groups to form the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel SBU with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 2.639(2) Å. Cu-O distances fall in the range from 1.937(3) to 1.983(5) Å, while Cu-N bond length is 2.139(6) Å, in accordance with the typical values observed in other copper-paddlewheel SBUs. Each L1 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form NbO topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {64⋅82} calculated with TOPOS. Two identical NbO networks are further bound together via the Cu-N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in a different single network, and then the self-interpenetrating 3,6T18 MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4⋅62}2{42⋅610⋅83} calculated with TOPOS. Despite the presentation of self-interpenetrating structure, two types of 1D channels are still retained in the final packing structure (a,b). The diameters of hexagonal and trigonal channels are about 1.1 and 0.4 nm measured from the crystal structure. Only one nitrogen atom in triazole is used to coordinate with copper atoms, and the other one is reserved and decorated on the surface of channels. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 70.2% (12601.0 Å3/17955.0 Å3) by PLATON.

elements.content: Perspective view of asymmetric unit of 1 (a) and 2 (b) with selected atom labeling (H atoms were omitted for clarity). Asymmetric codes: For 1: A, 1-x, 1-y, 2-z; B, 2/3-x+y, 4/3-x, z-2/3; C, 2/3+x-y, 1/3+x, 4/3-z; D, 1-x, 1-y, 1-z. For 2: A, -x, 3/2-y, z; B, −3/4+y, 1/4-x, 1/4+z; C, 3/4-y, 1/4+x, 1/4+z; D, 1/2+x, y, 1/2-z.
elements.clean_text: 1  Perspective view of asymmetric unit of 1 (a) and 2 (b) with selected atom labeling (H atoms were omitted for clarity). Asymmetric codes: For 1: A, 1-x, 1-y, 2-z; B, 2/3-x+y, 4/3-x, z-2/3; C, 2/3+x-y, 1/3+x, 4/3-z; D, 1-x, 1-y, 1-z. For 2: A, -x, 3/2-y, z; B, -3/4+y, 1/4-x, 1/4+z; C, 3/4-y, 1/4+x, 1/4+z; D, 1/2+x, y, 1/2-z.

elements.content: Partial view of the self-interpenetrating packing mode and topological structure of 1 (a, b) and 2 (c, d).
elements.clean_text: 2  Partial view of the self-interpenetrating packing mode and topological structure of 1 (a, b) and 2 (c, d).

elements.content: Differently, substituting L1 with L2, a new self-interpenetrating MOF had been constructed. 2 crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a, whose asymmetric unit also contains one copper atom and one L2 ligand (b). The coordination environments of copper atom is similar to the ones in 1, and the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel with Cu···Cu distance of 2.629(2) Å could be also presented. Cu–O distances fall in the range from 1.933(3) to 2.033(5) Å, while the Cu–N bond length is 2.094(4) Å, also in accordance with the typical values. Each L2 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form dia topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {66} calculated with TOPOS. The same two dia networks are further bound together via the Cu–N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in different single networks, and then the self-interpenetrating Flu MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4·62}2{42·67·86} calculated with TOPOS (c,d). The irregular porosities are still retained in the final packing structure. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 66.7% (9684.2 Å3/14524.0 Å3) by PLATON.
elements.clean_text: Differently, substituting L1 with L2, a new self-interpenetrating MOF had been constructed. 2 crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a, whose asymmetric unit also contains one copper atom and one L2 ligand (b). The coordination environments of copper atom is similar to the ones in 1, and the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 2.629(2) Å could be also presented. Cu-O distances fall in the range from 1.933(3) to 2.033(5) Å, while the Cu-N bond length is 2.094(4) Å, also in accordance with the typical values. Each L2 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form dia topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {66} calculated with TOPOS. The same two dia networks are further bound together via the Cu-N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in different single networks, and then the self-interpenetrating Flu MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4⋅62}2{42⋅67⋅86} calculated with TOPOS (c,d). The irregular porosities are still retained in the final packing structure. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 66.7% (9684.2 Å3/14524.0 Å3) by PLATON.

elements.content: Compared to the geometric parameters of components in 1 and 2, the difference between the angles such as C···carboxyl C central···C carboxyl and C carboxyl···N central···C carboxyl angles, dihedral angles of two benzoic units, must be responsible for the origination of different topologies (). The geometric configurations related with the triazole and SBU are similar in 1 and 2. The two angles in L1 are 123.7(1)° and 59.7(4)°, and the values in L2 are 115.1(3)° and 69.3(1)°. The C carboxyl···N central···C carboxyl angle in L1 around 120° would be beneficial for assembly of a hexagonal grid with the consideration of proper spatial tension, while the C carboxyl···C central···C carboxyl angle in L2 around 109.5° might be proper for the formation of diamond topology. The relative dihedral angles of different benzene rings in 1 and 2 would release the strain originating from the connection of SBUs and different ligands with the preset conformation. Subsequently, two different self-interpenetrating MOFs have been built utilizing similar ligands, which emphasizes the important role of ligands in constructing the anticipated porous MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Compared to the geometric parameters of components in 1 and 2, the difference between the angles such as C⋅⋅⋅carboxyl C central⋅⋅⋅C carboxyl and C carboxyl⋅⋅⋅N central⋅⋅⋅C carboxyl angles, dihedral angles of two benzoic units, must be responsible for the origination of different topologies (). The geometric configurations related with the triazole and SBU are similar in 1 and 2. The two angles in L1 are 123.7(1)° and 59.7(4)°, and the values in L2 are 115.1(3)° and 69.3(1)°. The C carboxyl⋅⋅⋅N central⋅⋅⋅C carboxyl angle in L1 around 120° would be beneficial for assembly of a hexagonal grid with the consideration of proper spatial tension, while the C carboxyl⋅⋅⋅C central⋅⋅⋅C carboxyl angle in L2 around 109.5° might be proper for the formation of diamond topology. The relative dihedral angles of different benzene rings in 1 and 2 would release the strain originating from the connection of SBUs and different ligands with the preset conformation. Subsequently, two different self-interpenetrating MOFs have been built utilizing similar ligands, which emphasizes the important role of ligands in constructing the anticipated porous MOFs.

elements.content: Geometric comparison of building components in 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  Geometric comparison of building components in 1 and 2.

elements.content: The purity of as-synthesized samples 1 and 2 has been confirmed by PXRD experiments and matches well with the simulations from the crystal data (). In order to explore the stability of 1 and 2, the samples of 1 and 2 were first immersed in deionized water at room temperature, separately. The PXRD pattern of the water-treated samples corresponds well with those of pristine samples, indicating that the structures of 1 and 2 are well-retained in water (). Furthermore, the PXRD of 1 and 2 in weak acidic and basic aqueous solutions revealed their different framework stabilities. After being treated with the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 3, 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9, 11) for 12 h at room temperature, the PXRD patterns of the samples still retain diffraction peaks of 1 (a), whereas the samples of 2 could only retain diffraction peaks in the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9) for 6 h at room temperature (b). As shown in , the thermogravimetry curve of 1 shows a slow weight loss of 32.4% from room temperature to 245 °C due to the escape of solvent molecules in 1. The main skeleton framework starts to decompose with an increase in temperature from 330 °C. TGA curve of 2 shows a continuous weight loss of 44.6% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules in the lattice of 2 (). The structure can stable up to 310 °C, and then the rapid weight loss could be attributed to the collapse of the framework of 2.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermal Stability of 1 and 2 

The purity of as-synthesized samples 1 and 2 has been confirmed by PXRD experiments and matches well with the simulations from the crystal data (). In order to explore the stability of 1 and 2, the samples of 1 and 2 were first immersed in deionized water at room temperature, separately. The PXRD pattern of the water-treated samples corresponds well with those of pristine samples, indicating that the structures of 1 and 2 are well-retained in water (). Furthermore, the PXRD of 1 and 2 in weak acidic and basic aqueous solutions revealed their different framework stabilities. After being treated with the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 3, 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9, 11) for 12 h at room temperature, the PXRD patterns of the samples still retain diffraction peaks of 1 (a), whereas the samples of 2 could only retain diffraction peaks in the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9) for 6 h at room temperature (b). As shown in , the thermogravimetry curve of 1 shows a slow weight loss of 32.4% from room temperature to 245 °C due to the escape of solvent molecules in 1. The main skeleton framework starts to decompose with an increase in temperature from 330 °C. TGA curve of 2 shows a continuous weight loss of 44.6% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules in the lattice of 2 (). The structure can stable up to 310 °C, and then the rapid weight loss could be attributed to the collapse of the framework of 2.

elements.content: PXRD patterns for as-synthesized 1 (a) and 2 (b) after being treated with weak acidic and basic aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text: 4  PXRD patterns for as-synthesized 1 (a) and 2 (b) after being treated with weak acidic and basic aqueous solutions.

elements.content: The high stabilities endow the potential for two self-interpenetrating MOFs as adsorption materials, which encourages us to further explore their adsorption capacities. The permanent porosities of 1 and 2 have been validated via N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (a), which show typical Type-I adsorption isotherms for microporous materials, in accordance with the results of structural analysis. The activated samples of 1 adsorbs 246 cm3 g–1 N2 at low temperature, which gives the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of 796 m2/g and 1054 m2/g, respectively. Comparably, the adsorption amount of 2 for N2 is 165 cm3 g–1 at low temperature, which gives the BET and Langmuir surface areas of 535 m2/g and 707 m2/g, respectively. Larger porous surface area of 1 was observed compared to 2, which is consistent with the results observed from the structural analysis. Furthermore, the C2H2 and CO2 uptake capacities of two self-interpenetrating MOFs were also measured (b). CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2 are 45.2 and 24.5 cm3 g–1 at 293 K and 1 atm, respectively. These amounts are not very large, which might be ascribed to the lack of open metal sites since the axial position of copper ions are occupied by nitrogen atoms. However, both of these MOFs exhibit the higher affinities toward C2H2 than CO2, with the amounts of 92.1 and 39.5 cm3 g–1, which exhibit the moderate adsorption C2H2/CO2 selectivity. The nitrogen-rich porous structures might be responsible for the moderate selectivity. In addition, the different capacity of C2H2 might be caused by the specific porous structures and surface in 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

The high stabilities endow the potential for two self-interpenetrating MOFs as adsorption materials, which encourages us to further explore their adsorption capacities. The permanent porosities of 1 and 2 have been validated via N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (a), which show typical Type-I adsorption isotherms for microporous materials, in accordance with the results of structural analysis. The activated samples of 1 adsorbs 246 cm3 g-1 N2 at low temperature, which gives the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of 796 m2/g and 1054 m2/g, respectively. Comparably, the adsorption amount of 2 for N2 is 165 cm3 g-1 at low temperature, which gives the BET and Langmuir surface areas of 535 m2/g and 707 m2/g, respectively. Larger porous surface area of 1 was observed compared to 2, which is consistent with the results observed from the structural analysis. Furthermore, the C2H2 and CO2 uptake capacities of two self-interpenetrating MOFs were also measured (b). CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2 are 45.2 and 24.5 cm3 g-1 at 293 K and 1 atm, respectively. These amounts are not very large, which might be ascribed to the lack of open metal sites since the axial position of copper ions are occupied by nitrogen atoms. However, both of these MOFs exhibit the higher affinities toward C2H2 than CO2, with the amounts of 92.1 and 39.5 cm3 g-1, which exhibit the moderate adsorption C2H2/CO2 selectivity. The nitrogen-rich porous structures might be responsible for the moderate selectivity. In addition, the different capacity of C2H2 might be caused by the specific porous structures and surface in 1 and 2.

elements.content: N2 physisorption isotherms for 1 and 2 at 77 K (a); CO2 and C2H2 adsorption isotherms at 293 K (b), respectively.
elements.clean_text: 5  N2 physisorption isotherms for 1 and 2 at 77 K (a); CO2 and C2H2 adsorption isotherms at 293 K (b), respectively.

elements.content: To further identify the adsorption mechanism of CO2 and C2H2 on two Cu-MOFs, density functional theory calculations were carried out by using DMol3 software. Because of the difficulty in probing the adsorption site on the whole framework of two Cu-MOFs, the core part of the structure containing a Cu2 paddlewheel and six ligands was isolated and taken into account. First, hydrogen atoms were relaxed under the constraint of non-hydrogen atoms, and subsequently all atoms were fully optimized. Then, adsorption structures containing the molecules of CO2 and C2H2 were also set up and investigated. The obtained adsorption energy of C2H2 is −13.94 kcal/mol for 1 and −12.63 kcal/mol for 2, respectively. While those values for CO2 is −8.70 kcal/mol for 1 and −6.71 kcal/mol for 2. All of these values reveal the characteristic of weak physical adsorption between adsorbent and two Cu-MOFs. In addition, the difference in adsorption-energy of CO2 and C2H2 also validate that whatever 1 or 2 is inclined to adsorb C2H2, and 1 exhibits higher adsorption ability compared to 2, which all are in consistent with the experimental results.
elements.clean_text: To further identify the adsorption mechanism of CO2 and C2H2 on two Cu-MOFs, density functional theory calculations were carried out by using DMol3 software. Because of the difficulty in probing the adsorption site on the whole framework of two Cu-MOFs, the core part of the structure containing a Cu2 paddlewheel and six ligands was isolated and taken into account. First, hydrogen atoms were relaxed under the constraint of non-hydrogen atoms, and subsequently all atoms were fully optimized. Then, adsorption structures containing the molecules of CO2 and C2H2 were also set up and investigated. The obtained adsorption energy of C2H2 is -13.94 kcal/mol for 1 and -12.63 kcal/mol for 2, respectively. While those values for CO2 is -8.70 kcal/mol for 1 and -6.71 kcal/mol for 2. All of these values reveal the characteristic of weak physical adsorption between adsorbent and two Cu-MOFs. In addition, the difference in adsorption-energy of CO2 and C2H2 also validate that whatever 1 or 2 is inclined to adsorb C2H2, and 1 exhibits higher adsorption ability compared to 2, which all are in consistent with the experimental results.

elements.content: Furthermore, viewed from the theoretical adsorption structures, it could be found that CO2 or C2H2 molecules prefer to adsorb on the vicinity of Cu2O8N2 building block (). Electron density figures () show that weak interaction (e.g., electrostatic interaction) appears between adsorbates and the Cu2O8N2 building block. Furthermore, the adsorption position could also be supported by the results of calculations of frontier molecular orbitals. The corresponding frontier molecular orbitals of two Cu-MOFs indicate that HOMO–2, HOMO–1, HOMO, and LUMO, consisting of 3d orbitals of Cu and π-type antibonding orbitals of conjugate moiety, mainly concentrate on Cu2O8N2 building blocks and triazole moiety of ligands (), which also verified that the vicinity of the building block is an optimal adsorption site for CO2 and C2H2 molecules. Moreover, molecular dynamic simulations at 300 K (see ) also validate these results.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, viewed from the theoretical adsorption structures, it could be found that CO2 or C2H2 molecules prefer to adsorb on the vicinity of Cu2O8N2 building block (). Electron density figures () show that weak interaction (e.g., electrostatic interaction) appears between adsorbates and the Cu2O8N2 building block. Furthermore, the adsorption position could also be supported by the results of calculations of frontier molecular orbitals. The corresponding frontier molecular orbitals of two Cu-MOFs indicate that HOMO-2, HOMO-1, HOMO, and LUMO, consisting of 3d orbitals of Cu and π-type antibonding orbitals of conjugate moiety, mainly concentrate on Cu2O8N2 building blocks and triazole moiety of ligands (), which also verified that the vicinity of the building block is an optimal adsorption site for CO2 and C2H2 molecules. Moreover, molecular dynamic simulations at 300 K (see ) also validate these results.

elements.content: Electron density of C2H2 (a, c) and CO2 (b, d) on adsorption structure of two types of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: 6  Electron density of C2H2 (a, c) and CO2 (b, d) on adsorption structure of two types of MOFs.

elements.content: In summary, two novel self-interpenetrating MOFs have been successfully constructed by utilizing two similar bifunctional triazolate–carboxylate ligands. In addition, the different framework stabilities and pore environments of Cu-MOFs 1–2 have been explored by powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry, gas sorption, and theoretical calculations. The preset configurations and connection modes of different ligands must be responsible for the assembly of distinct topological structures with favorable stabilities and porosities. The results presented show that the careful predesign of organic components of MOFs is very vital to building a highly porous framework with self-interpenetrating topological structures, which encourages further investigations on the rational construction of related materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two novel self-interpenetrating MOFs have been successfully constructed by utilizing two similar bifunctional triazolate-carboxylate ligands. In addition, the different framework stabilities and pore environments of Cu-MOFs 1-2 have been explored by powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetry, gas sorption, and theoretical calculations. The preset configurations and connection modes of different ligands must be responsible for the assembly of distinct topological structures with favorable stabilities and porosities. The results presented show that the careful predesign of organic components of MOFs is very vital to building a highly porous framework with self-interpenetrating topological structures, which encourages further investigations on the rational construction of related materials.

cln_elements.content:
1 is in trigonal space group R3̅, whose asymmetric unit contains one copper atom and one L1 ligand (a). The copper atom adopts five-coordinated square-pyramidal geometry, and coordinates with four oxygen atoms from the different carboxyls of L1 and one nitrogen atom of triazole. The adjacent copper atoms are bound together via four syn-syn carboxyl groups to form the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel SBU with Cu···Cu distance of 2.639(2) Å. Cu–O distances fall in the range from 1.937(3) to 1.983(5) Å, while Cu–N bond length is 2.139(6) Å, in accordance with the typical values observed in other copper-paddlewheel SBUs. Each L1 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form NbO topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {64·82} calculated with TOPOS. Two identical NbO networks are further bound together via the Cu–N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in a different single network, and then the self-interpenetrating 3,6T18 MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4·62}2{42·610·83} calculated with TOPOS. Despite the presentation of self-interpenetrating structure, two types of 1D channels are still retained in the final packing structure (a,b). The diameters of hexagonal and trigonal channels are about 1.1 and 0.4 nm measured from the crystal structure. Only one nitrogen atom in triazole is used to coordinate with copper atoms, and the other one is reserved and decorated on the surface of channels. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 70.2% (12601.0 Å3/17955.0 Å3) by PLATON.

Differently, substituting L1 with L2, a new self-interpenetrating MOF had been constructed. 2 crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a, whose asymmetric unit also contains one copper atom and one L2 ligand (b). The coordination environments of copper atom is similar to the ones in 1, and the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel with Cu···Cu distance of 2.629(2) Å could be also presented. Cu–O distances fall in the range from 1.933(3) to 2.033(5) Å, while the Cu–N bond length is 2.094(4) Å, also in accordance with the typical values. Each L2 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form dia topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {66} calculated with TOPOS. The same two dia networks are further bound together via the Cu–N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in different single networks, and then the self-interpenetrating Flu MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4·62}2{42·67·86} calculated with TOPOS (c,d). The irregular porosities are still retained in the final packing structure. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 66.7% (9684.2 Å3/14524.0 Å3) by PLATON.

PXRD and Thermal Stability of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold>

The purity of as-synthesized samples 1 and 2 has been confirmed by PXRD experiments and matches well with the simulations from the crystal data (). In order to explore the stability of 1 and 2, the samples of 1 and 2 were first immersed in deionized water at room temperature, separately. The PXRD pattern of the water-treated samples corresponds well with those of pristine samples, indicating that the structures of 1 and 2 are well-retained in water (). Furthermore, the PXRD of 1 and 2 in weak acidic and basic aqueous solutions revealed their different framework stabilities. After being treated with the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 3, 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9, 11) for 12 h at room temperature, the PXRD patterns of the samples still retain diffraction peaks of 1 (a), whereas the samples of 2 could only retain diffraction peaks in the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9) for 6 h at room temperature (b). As shown in , the thermogravimetry curve of 1 shows a slow weight loss of 32.4% from room temperature to 245 °C due to the escape of solvent molecules in 1. The main skeleton framework starts to decompose with an increase in temperature from 330 °C. TGA curve of 2 shows a continuous weight loss of 44.6% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules in the lattice of 2 (). The structure can stable up to 310 °C, and then the rapid weight loss could be attributed to the collapse of the framework of 2.

Gas Sorption Properties

The high stabilities endow the potential for two self-interpenetrating MOFs as adsorption materials, which encourages us to further explore their adsorption capacities. The permanent porosities of 1 and 2 have been validated via N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (a), which show typical Type-I adsorption isotherms for microporous materials, in accordance with the results of structural analysis. The activated samples of 1 adsorbs 246 cm3 g–1 N2 at low temperature, which gives the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of 796 m2/g and 1054 m2/g, respectively. Comparably, the adsorption amount of 2 for N2 is 165 cm3 g–1 at low temperature, which gives the BET and Langmuir surface areas of 535 m2/g and 707 m2/g, respectively. Larger porous surface area of 1 was observed compared to 2, which is consistent with the results observed from the structural analysis. Furthermore, the C2H2 and CO2 uptake capacities of two self-interpenetrating MOFs were also measured (b). CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2 are 45.2 and 24.5 cm3 g–1 at 293 K and 1 atm, respectively. These amounts are not very large, which might be ascribed to the lack of open metal sites since the axial position of copper ions are occupied by nitrogen atoms. However, both of these MOFs exhibit the higher affinities toward C2H2 than CO2, with the amounts of 92.1 and 39.5 cm3 g–1, which exhibit the moderate adsorption C2H2/CO2 selectivity. The nitrogen-rich porous structures might be responsible for the moderate selectivity. In addition, the different capacity of C2H2 might be caused by the specific porous structures and surface in 1 and 2.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 1 and 2 

 1 is in trigonal space group R3̅, whose asymmetric unit contains one copper atom and one L1 ligand (a). The copper atom adopts five-coordinated square-pyramidal geometry, and coordinates with four oxygen atoms from the different carboxyls of L1 and one nitrogen atom of triazole. The adjacent copper atoms are bound together via four syn-syn carboxyl groups to form the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel SBU with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 2.639(2) Å. Cu-O distances fall in the range from 1.937(3) to 1.983(5) Å, while Cu-N bond length is 2.139(6) Å, in accordance with the typical values observed in other copper-paddlewheel SBUs. Each L1 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form NbO topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {64⋅82} calculated with TOPOS. Two identical NbO networks are further bound together via the Cu-N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in a different single network, and then the self-interpenetrating 3,6T18 MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4⋅62}2{42⋅610⋅83} calculated with TOPOS. Despite the presentation of self-interpenetrating structure, two types of 1D channels are still retained in the final packing structure (a,b). The diameters of hexagonal and trigonal channels are about 1.1 and 0.4 nm measured from the crystal structure. Only one nitrogen atom in triazole is used to coordinate with copper atoms, and the other one is reserved and decorated on the surface of channels. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 70.2% (12601.0 Å3/17955.0 Å3) by PLATON. 

Differently, substituting L1 with L2, a new self-interpenetrating MOF had been constructed. 2 crystallizes in tetragonal space group I41/a, whose asymmetric unit also contains one copper atom and one L2 ligand (b). The coordination environments of copper atom is similar to the ones in 1, and the Cu2(COO)4 paddlewheel with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 2.629(2) Å could be also presented. Cu-O distances fall in the range from 1.933(3) to 2.033(5) Å, while the Cu-N bond length is 2.094(4) Å, also in accordance with the typical values. Each L2 ligand utilizes its two carboxyl groups to connect two paddlewheel SBUs to form dia topological structure with the point Schläfli symbol {66} calculated with TOPOS. The same two dia networks are further bound together via the Cu-N coordination bonds from triazole groups and paddlewheel SBUs in different single networks, and then the self-interpenetrating Flu MOF has been obtained with the point Schläfli symbol {4⋅62}2{42⋅67⋅86} calculated with TOPOS (c,d). The irregular porosities are still retained in the final packing structure. The solvent accessible volume is calculated as 66.7% (9684.2 Å3/14524.0 Å3) by PLATON. 

PXRD and Thermal Stability of 1 and 2 

The purity of as-synthesized samples 1 and 2 has been confirmed by PXRD experiments and matches well with the simulations from the crystal data (). In order to explore the stability of 1 and 2, the samples of 1 and 2 were first immersed in deionized water at room temperature, separately. The PXRD pattern of the water-treated samples corresponds well with those of pristine samples, indicating that the structures of 1 and 2 are well-retained in water (). Furthermore, the PXRD of 1 and 2 in weak acidic and basic aqueous solutions revealed their different framework stabilities. After being treated with the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 3, 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9, 11) for 12 h at room temperature, the PXRD patterns of the samples still retain diffraction peaks of 1 (a), whereas the samples of 2 could only retain diffraction peaks in the HCl aqueous solutions (pH = 5) or the NaOH aqueous solutions (pH = 9) for 6 h at room temperature (b). As shown in , the thermogravimetry curve of 1 shows a slow weight loss of 32.4% from room temperature to 245 °C due to the escape of solvent molecules in 1. The main skeleton framework starts to decompose with an increase in temperature from 330 °C. TGA curve of 2 shows a continuous weight loss of 44.6% from room temperature to 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of solvent molecules in the lattice of 2 (). The structure can stable up to 310 °C, and then the rapid weight loss could be attributed to the collapse of the framework of 2.

Gas Sorption Properties

The high stabilities endow the potential for two self-interpenetrating MOFs as adsorption materials, which encourages us to further explore their adsorption capacities. The permanent porosities of 1 and 2 have been validated via N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (a), which show typical Type-I adsorption isotherms for microporous materials, in accordance with the results of structural analysis. The activated samples of 1 adsorbs 246 cm3 g-1 N2 at low temperature, which gives the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of 796 m2/g and 1054 m2/g, respectively. Comparably, the adsorption amount of 2 for N2 is 165 cm3 g-1 at low temperature, which gives the BET and Langmuir surface areas of 535 m2/g and 707 m2/g, respectively. Larger porous surface area of 1 was observed compared to 2, which is consistent with the results observed from the structural analysis. Furthermore, the C2H2 and CO2 uptake capacities of two self-interpenetrating MOFs were also measured (b). CO2 uptake capacities of 1 and 2 are 45.2 and 24.5 cm3 g-1 at 293 K and 1 atm, respectively. These amounts are not very large, which might be ascribed to the lack of open metal sites since the axial position of copper ions are occupied by nitrogen atoms. However, both of these MOFs exhibit the higher affinities toward C2H2 than CO2, with the amounts of 92.1 and 39.5 cm3 g-1, which exhibit the moderate adsorption C2H2/CO2 selectivity. The nitrogen-rich porous structures might be responsible for the moderate selectivity. In addition, the different capacity of C2H2 might be caused by the specific porous structures and surface in 1 and 2.

cln_elements.content: Perspective view of asymmetric unit of 1 (a) and 2 (b) with selected atom labeling (H atoms were omitted for clarity). Asymmetric codes: For 1: A, 1-x, 1-y, 2-z; B, 2/3-x+y, 4/3-x, z-2/3; C, 2/3+x-y, 1/3+x, 4/3-z; D, 1-x, 1-y, 1-z. For 2: A, -x, 3/2-y, z; B, −3/4+y, 1/4-x, 1/4+z; C, 3/4-y, 1/4+x, 1/4+z; D, 1/2+x, y, 1/2-z.

metadata.title:
Two Self-Interpenetrating
Copper(II)-Paddlewheel Metal–Organic
Frameworks Constructed from Bifunctional Triazolate–Carboxylate
Linkers
